reasoning: The critique targets the “long views win” (2.3.3) optimism that patience/non-discounting might select for altruistic values. That point is only one subsidiary consideration in the overall essay (which is largely pessimistic about WAM-convergence and then focuses on partial convergence + trade/threats), so centrality is low-moderate. Substantively, the critique makes a real point: patience can amplify strategic capability (credible commitment, bargaining leverage) and so plausibly selects for agents good at commitment/threat dynamics rather than altruism per se, which undercuts a key optimistic reading of 2.3.3. However, the main essay already anticipates much of this direction (non-discounting needn’t be altruistic; threats can undermine trade; limited time for selection), so the critique weakens rather than overturns the relevant claims. Several assertions are plausibly true but overstated/speculative (e.g., that this selection pressure ‘tends toward’ coercive bargaining and is ‘not an adjustable parameter’), reducing correctness somewhat. The critique is clear, focused, and contains little irrelevant material.
title: Patient agents select for commitment power, not altruism
